name: Andromeda
description: Known for containing the Andromeda Galaxy (M31), the closest major galaxy to the Milky Way.

name: Antlia
description: A faint constellation in the Southern Hemisphere, representing the air pump invented by Denis Papin.

name: Apus
description: A small, faint constellation near the south celestial pole, first depicted in the late 16th century.

name: Aquarius
description: A constellation of the zodiac, located in a region often called the Sea due to its profusion of watery constellations.

name: Aquila
description: Located on the celestial equator, its brightest star is Altair, one of the vertices of the Summer Triangle.

name: Ara
description: A southern constellation situated between Scorpius and Triangulum Australe, rich in Milky Way star fields.

name: Aries
description: One of the constellations of the zodiac, its brightest stars are Hamal and Sheratan.

name: Auriga
description: A large northern constellation, its brightest star Capella is a prominent feature of the winter sky.

name: Bo√∂tes
description: Home to Arcturus, the third-brightest individual star in the night sky.

name: Caelum
description: A faint, small constellation introduced by Nicolas-Louis de Lacaille in the 18th century.

name: Camelopardalis
description: A large but faint northern constellation, representing a giraffe.

name: Cancer
description: A medium-sized constellation of the zodiac, known for the Beehive Cluster (Praesepe or M44).

name: Canes Venatici
description: A small northern constellation created by Johannes Hevelius, containing the Whirlpool Galaxy (M51).

name: Canis Major
description: Represents the greater dog following Orion, and contains Sirius, the brightest star in the night sky.

name: Canis Minor
description: A small constellation representing the lesser dog, its brightest star is Procyon.

name: Capricornus
description: One of the constellations of the zodiac, often depicted as a mythical creature that is half goat, half fish.

name: Carina
description: Part of the former giant constellation Argo Navis, it contains Canopus, the second-brightest star in the sky, and the spectacular Carina Nebula.

name: Cassiopeia
description: Easily recognizable by its distinctive 'W' or 'M' shape, formed by five bright stars.

name: Centaurus
description: A large, bright southern constellation, home to Alpha Centauri, the closest star system to the Sun.

name: Cepheus
description: Represents a king in Greek mythology, located near Cassiopeia and Draco.

name: Cetus
description: A giant constellation in a region of the sky called the Water, it contains the remarkable variable star Mira.

name: Chamaeleon
description: A small, faint constellation near the south celestial pole, named after the lizard.

name: Circinus
description: A small, faint constellation representing a draftsman's compass.

name: Columba
description: A small, faint constellation located just south of Canis Major and Lepus.

name: Coma Berenices
description: The only modern constellation named for a historical figure, Queen Berenice II of Egypt. It contains the North Galactic Pole.

name: Corona Australis
description: A small constellation whose brightest stars form a distinctive semicircle.

name: Corona Borealis
description: A small northern constellation whose main stars form a semicircular arc.

name: Corvus
description: A small constellation easily identified by a quadrilateral of four bright stars.

name: Crater
description: A faint constellation representing the cup of the god Apollo.

name: Crux
description: The smallest of the 88 modern constellations but also one of the most distinctive. It is a crucial navigational tool in the Southern Hemisphere.

name: Cygnus
description: A prominent northern constellation lying on the plane of the Milky Way, it features the Northern Cross asterism. Its brightest star is Deneb.

name: Delphinus
description: A small but distinctive northern constellation, easily recognizable for its diamond-shaped pattern of stars known as Job's Coffin.

name: Dorado
description: A southern constellation containing most of the Large Magellanic Cloud, a satellite galaxy of the Milky Way.

name: Draco
description: A long, winding northern constellation that wraps around the north celestial pole.

name: Equuleus
description: The second-smallest modern constellation, representing a foal or small horse.

name: Eridanus
description: A long, meandering constellation that starts near Orion and flows southward, ending with the bright star Achernar.

name: Fornax
description: A faint southern constellation, named by Nicolas-Louis de Lacaille to represent a chemical furnace.

name: Gemini
description: A zodiac constellation known for its two brightest stars, Castor and Pollux, which represent the mythological twins.

name: Grus
description: A southern constellation, one of the twelve created by Petrus Plancius from the observations of Pieter Dirkszoon Keyser and Frederick de Houtman.

name: Hercules
description: Named after the Roman mythological hero, it contains the Keystone asterism and the great globular cluster M13.

name: Horologium
description: A faint southern constellation introduced by Nicolas-Louis de Lacaille.

name: Hydra
description: The largest of the 88 modern constellations, stretching across more than 100 degrees of the sky.

name: Hydrus
description: A small constellation deep in the southern sky, not to be confused with the much larger Hydra.

name: Indus
description: A southern constellation first appearing on a celestial globe in the late 16th century.

name: Lacerta
description: A small, faint northern constellation sometimes referred to as 'Little Cassiopeia' due to its 'W' shape.

name: Leo
description: One of the most recognizable constellations of the zodiac, its head and mane form an asterism known as the Sickle.

name: Leo Minor
description: A small, faint constellation located between the much larger Leo and Ursa Major.

name: Lepus
description: A constellation located just south of Orion, often depicted as a hare being chased by the hunter or his dogs.

name: Libra
description: A constellation of the zodiac, it is the only one that represents an inanimate object.

name: Lupus
description: A southern constellation located between Centaurus and Scorpius.

name: Lynx
description: A faint northern constellation, said to be named because one needs the eyesight of a lynx to see it.

name: Lyra
description: A small constellation known for its brightest star, Vega, which is one of the vertices of the Summer Triangle. It also contains the Ring Nebula (M57).

name: Mensa
description: The faintest constellation in the sky, named after Table Mountain in South Africa. Part of the Large Magellanic Cloud dips into it.

name: Microscopium
description: A minor southern constellation, one of several scientific instruments placed in the sky by Nicolas-Louis de Lacaille.

name: Monoceros
description: A faint constellation on the celestial equator, containing the Rosette Nebula.

name: Musca
description: A small constellation deep in the southern sky, adjacent to Crux.

name: Norma
description: A small, faint constellation in the Southern Hemisphere between Ara and Lupus.

name: Octans
description: A faint circumpolar constellation whose main distinction is containing the south celestial pole.

name: Ophiuchus
description: A large constellation often called the '13th zodiac constellation' because the Sun passes through it. It divides the constellation Serpens into two parts.

name: Orion
description: A prominent constellation visible throughout the world. It is one of the most recognizable constellations, identified by the three bright stars of Orion's Belt.

name: Pavo
description: A southern constellation with one bright star, also named Peacock (Alpha Pavonis).

name: Pegasus
description: A large northern constellation, dominated by a prominent asterism known as the Great Square of Pegasus.

name: Perseus
description: Named after the Greek hero Perseus, this constellation is the radiant of the annual Perseid meteor shower.

name: Phoenix
description: A minor southern constellation, named after the mythical bird that is cyclically reborn from ashes.

name: Pictor
description: A small, faint southern constellation, notable for containing Beta Pictoris, a star with a surrounding dust disk.

name: Pisces
description: A large but faint constellation of the zodiac, its stars form a large 'V' shape.

name: Piscis Austrinus
description: A southern constellation whose only bright star is Fomalhaut.

name: Puppis
description: The largest of the three constellations that once formed Argo Navis, representing the stern or poop deck of the ship.

name: Pyxis
description: A small, faint southern constellation, representing a ship's compass.

name: Reticulum
description: A small southern constellation whose brightest stars form a diamond-like shape (rhomboid).

name: Sagitta
description: The third-smallest constellation, its stars form a shape resembling an arrow.

name: Sagittarius
description: A zodiac constellation, it contains a prominent asterism known as the Teapot and lies in the direction of the center of the Milky Way.

name: Scorpius
description: A large constellation near the center of the Milky Way, easily identifiable by the bright, reddish star Antares.

name: Sculptor
description: A faint southern constellation containing the south galactic pole.

name: Scutum
description: A small constellation introduced in the 17th century, it lies within the Milky Way.

name: Serpens
description: Unique among the modern constellations in that it is split into two non-contiguous parts, Serpens Caput (the head) and Serpens Cauda (the tail), separated by Ophiuchus.

name: Sextans
description: A faint equatorial constellation introduced by Johannes Hevelius.

name: Taurus
description: A large and prominent zodiac constellation, it contains the bright star Aldebaran and the famous Pleiades and Hyades star clusters.

name: Telescopium
description: A small, faint southern constellation created in the 18th century by Nicolas-Louis de Lacaille.

name: Triangulum
description: A small northern constellation whose three brightest stars form a long, narrow triangle. It contains the Triangulum Galaxy (M33).

name: Triangulum Australe
description: A small southern constellation whose three brightest stars form a roughly equilateral triangle.

name: Tucana
description: A southern constellation containing most of the Small Magellanic Cloud.

name: Ursa Major
description: One of the most famous constellations, known for containing the Big Dipper asterism. It is a key guide to finding the North Star, Polaris.

name: Ursa Minor
description: Also known as the Little Dipper, this northern constellation contains the north celestial pole and the North Star, Polaris.

name: Vela
description: Part of the former constellation Argo Navis, representing the sails of the ship.

name: Virgo
description: The largest constellation of the zodiac and the second-largest overall, its brightest star is Spica. It is rich in galaxies, containing the Virgo Cluster.

name: Volans
description: A small southern constellation, representing a type of tropical fish that can leap out of the water and glide on its fins.

name: Vulpecula
description: A faint northern constellation located in the middle of the Summer Triangle. It contains the Dumbbell Nebula (M27).
